sentences.sentence: Little Red-Cap
Once upon a time there was a little girl who was loved by everyone, but most of all by her grandmother.
Once she gave her a little red cap, which suited( 适合 ) her so well that she would never wear anything else; so she was always called “Little Red-Cap.”
One day her mother said to her, “Little Red-Cap, here is a piece of cake and a bottle of wine.
Take them to your grandmother.
She is ill and weak, and they will do her good.
Set out( 出发 )  before it gets hot, walk quietly and do not run off the path( 路 ), or you may fall and break the bottle, and then your grandmother will get nothing.
And when you go into her room, don’t forget to say, ‘Good morning,’ and don’t look into every corner before you do it.”
“I will take great care,” said Little Red-Cap to her mother.
The grandmother lived out in the forest, two miles from the village, and just as Little Red-Cap entered the forest, a wolf( 狼 ) met her.
Little Red-Cap did not know how wicked( 邪恶的 ) he was, and was not at all afraid of him.
“Good day, Little Red-Cap,” said he.
“Thank you kindly, wolf.”
“Where are you going so early, Little Red-Cap?”
“To my grandmother’s.”
“What are you carrying to her, Little Red-Cap?”
“Cake and wine. Mother baked( 烤 ) the cake yesterday, so poor sick grandmother is to have something good, to make her stronger.”
“Where does your grandmother live, Little Red-Cap?”
“About a mile farther on into the wood. Her house stands under the three large oak trees( 橡树 ), with some nut trees( 坚果树 ) nearby. You surely must know it,” replied Little Red-Cap.
The wolf thought to himself, “What a tender( 嫩的 ) young creature( 人 )! She looks delicious—far better to eat than the old woman. If I am clever, I can catch them both.”
So he walked for a short time by the side of Little Red-Cap, and then he said,
“See Little Red-Cap, how pretty the flowers are about here—why not look around?
You do not hear how sweetly the little birds are singing.
You walk seriously along as if you were going to school, while everything else out here in the wood is happy and carefree( 无忧无虑的 ).”
Little Red-Cap raised her eyes, and saw the sunlight dancing here and there through the trees, and pretty flowers growing everywhere.
She thought, “Suppose( 假如 ) I take grandmother some freshly picked flowers; that would please her too.
It is so early in the day that I shall still get there in good time.”
So she left the path and went further into the wood to look for( 寻找 )  flowers.
And whenever she had picked one, she thought that she saw an even prettier one farther on, and ran after it, and so got deeper and deeper into the wood.
Meanwhile( 与此同时 ) the wolf ran straight to the grandmother’s house and knocked at the door.
“Who is there?”
“Little Red-Cap,” replied the wolf.
“I am bringing cake and wine; open the door.”
“Lift the latch( 门闩 ),” called out the grandmother. “I am too weak, and cannot get up.”
The wolf lifted the latch and opened the door.
Without saying a word, he went straight to the grandmother’s bed, and ate her all up.
Then he put on her clothes, dressed himself in her cap, lay down in her bed, and closed the curtains( 床帷 ).
Little Red-Cap, however, had been running about picking flowers,
and when she had gathered( 采集 ) so many that she could carry no more, she remembered her grandmother, and set out on the way to her.
She was surprised to find the cottage( 小屋 ) door standing open,
and when she went into the room, she had such a strange feeling that she said to herself,
“Oh dear! How uneasy I feel today, even though at other times I like visiting grandmother so much.”
She called out, “Good morning,” but received no answer.
So she went to the bed, and got into it with her Grandma.
Her Grandma had the cap pulled over her face, and looked very strange.
“Oh! Grandmother,” she said, “what big ears you have!”
“The better to hear you with, my child,” was the reply.
“But, grandmother, what big eyes you have!” she said.
“The better to see you with, my dear.”
“But, grandmother, what large hands you have!”
“The better to hug( 抱 ) you with.”
“Oh! Grandmother, what a terribly big mouth you have!”
“The better to eat you with!”
And when the wolf had said this, then he jumped out of bed and swallowed( 吞咽 ) up Little Red-Cap.
